comment._content: Lovely family shot NLI and a great story.  They are a handsome bunch and the tennis rackets are so much more in keeping than a shotgun!

comment._content: The Nun is a Sister of Mercy founded in Dublin Ireland by Catherine McAuley in 1831...

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Peter O'Connor was involved in a very famous murder case(never solved) in County Waterford back in the 1930's, The Missing Postman

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I've added the names of the family with the help of Mark Quinn's book, The King of Spring, there is a family photo in it but taken some years later. Some of the names may be a little mixed up and might need correcting. The photo above might have been taken in Tramore but Peter lived in Newtown, Waterford until his death in 1957. Here is another earlier photo of the O'Connor family Mr P.O'Connor- Upton- family Upton was the name of the house where Peter lived from 1913 -1957.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Brilliant note/name adding, but no names for the two dogs?!   :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] That's a bizarre story! Wonder what ever happened him...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content:
Not sure about the names of the dogs I'm afraid, he had several over the years. There is a photo in the book taken probably in the 1940's that shows 3 of his dogs, Perky a Brindle Cairn terrier, Barney a smooth fox terrier and according to the book his most famous dog Jumper an Irish Red terrier.

Regarding the missing postman my dad always maintained he was probably buried under a new road that was being built at the time but who knows.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] I was only joking about the dogs!  :D
